update.description:
This is the fourth of the pull requests intended to replace an earlier pull request. The purpose of this series of pull requests is to do more removal of boost from sdformat. Each branch builds upon the last one, so we'll end up with a giant octopus merge in the end.  Note that this PR is requesting to merge into remove-boost-4 so we only see the differences here.  However, the ultimate goal of this PR is to merge onto default.

This particular PR removes most of boost from parser.cc



* Remove boost::trim, and implement our own version.

* Replace uses of boost::replace_all with our own home-grown version.

* Add in a new test file for the main parser.cc
update.title: Remove boost - from parser.cc (PR 4/5)

content.raw:
I see, thanks for the clarification. I just wonder if people needing `replace_all` in the future would find it here or would end up implementing their own again.

In any case, I think this is ok as it is.
content.html:
I see, thanks for the clarification. I just wonder if people needing replace_all in the future would find it here or would end up implementing their own again.

In any case, I think this is ok as it is.

content.raw: Another instance I missed.  I'll fix it.
content.html: Another instance I missed. I'll fix it.

content.raw: Sure, that's fine.  I think I copied that out of somewhere, but you are right, that comment isn't very helpful :).
content.html: Sure, that's fine. I think I copied that out of somewhere, but you are right, that comment isn't very helpful :).

content.raw: Ah, that's a style thing that I do.  If a function is only required by a single module, then I just put it into that module, no need to expose the symbol (you get a local symbol instead of a global one).  Once it is used by more than one module, I put it in a common place, and then you get a global symbol.  This matters more for C than C++, since we have namespaces in C++.  Still, I like to keep all of the code together unless it needs to be shared.
content.html: Ah, that's a style thing that I do. If a function is only required by a single module, then I just put it into that module, no need to expose the symbol (you get a local symbol instead of a global one). Once it is used by more than one module, I put it in a common place, and then you get a global symbol. This matters more for C than C++, since we have namespaces in C++. Still, I like to keep all of the code together unless it needs to be shared.

content.raw: I'm curious as to why `trim` went into `Types`, but `replace_all` is in `parser.cc`
content.html: I'm curious as to why trim went into Types, but replace_all is in parser.cc

content.raw: Prefix input params with `_`. There are a few other instances below as well.
content.html: Prefix input params with _. There are a few other instances below as well.
